title: Ant Middleton reveals massive 21kg weight loss after spending two months at sea on a raft filming new show Mutiny
text:
7 The SAS: Who Dares Wins hunk says the new show will be the toughest yet 
They were just dehydrated, malnourished, psychologically and physically drained. I could sit here and say everything was fine but it wasn’t you know, but I wouldn’t change anything.” 
Ant, who made his name as the lead instructor of Channel 4’s SAS: Who Dares Wins, captains a group of nine men to recreate one of the greatest survival feats in British history. Goff Photos Ant and his team sailed 4,000 in a 23ft boat Eamonn & James Clarke 7 Ant and his team embarked on a dangerous expedition 
The new show, which starts on March 6, sees Ant take up the role of Captain William Bligh, who was forced out onto a lifeboat in the middle of the Pacific Ocean in 1789 after a mutiny on his ship HMS Bounty . 
Bligh and his small crew somehow travelled through brutal storms and treacherous reefs all on a tiny 23ft wooden raft. 
Ant and co are now following their exact steps, using Bligh’s regularly updated journal that somehow survived the voyage. related stories MUTINY WILL SINK ITS RIVALS SAS: Who Dares Wins star Ant Middleton to launch survival show Mutiny which 'puts Bear Grylls' The Island to shame' YOU SHALL NOT PASS Ant Middleton doesn't want ANYONE to pass SAS: Who Dares Wins 'I get scared all the time' Despite his survival skills Bear Grylls reveals he's not as fearless as we all thought KEEPING OFF THE RADAR 'Bored' missing schoolboy, 15, could be using Bear Grylls' survival skills to stay alive DOTING DAD SAS: Who Dares Wins hunk Ant Middleton shows his softer side as he carries newborn son on a visit to shops BOUNTYFUL LIFESTYLE Britain's most remote island, where its 42 inhabitants got £18m of aid in just six years 
But despite having their progress, or lack of, tracked by cameras – there is a genuine risk of injury, or worse. 
A safety boat followed them, but it was more around five nautical miles behind them so if a crew member went overboard, there was little that could be done. Watch Who Dares Wins on Channel 4 with former soldier Ant Middleton 
And Ant insisted the boat was out of eyeline and earshot, to keep the experience authentic - and terrifying. 
He revealed: “We needed to be in that bubble we needed to maintain that state of mind it was very important from the beginning. 
“The thing about that is during the storms it doesn’t matter if you’ve got safety boats or a helicopter on standby. When it’s storming that helicopter’s not going to come near. News Group Newspapers Ltd 7 Ant presented at award at the Millies last year 
“The safety boat is there during the storms to basically mark our position. They couldn’t come in because it would just smash up against the boat and the heli couldn’t come in because it wouldn’t deal with the winds and the rain. 
“We still had to ride that storm out there’s nothing they could have done about it.” 
When asked if all of the crew make it out in one piece, he adds: “You’ll have to wait and see.”
